CHC120H1-F-20259.courseDescription: What is Catholicism, as an idea, as a social movement, as an object of scorn, devotion or delight? What meaning does Catholic tradition have in the contemporary world? This seminar explores these and similar questions through lectures and conversations with diverse scholars—faculty, fellows and friends—of the St. Michael’s College community.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

CHC130H1-S-20261.courseTitle: Playing with Fire: Alchemy, Astrology, and Magic
CHC130H1-S-20261.courseDescription: This course offers an historical introduction to alchemy, astrology, and magic, with a focus on the development, defence, condemnation, and progressive marginalization of these controversial pursuits in and around the Christian world(s). Students will learn about such topics as the search for the philosopher's stone, the casting of horoscopes, the design of wondrous machines… and the risks associated with meddling with spirits! Lectures will examine these learned traditions on their own terms, while inviting discussions about their enduring popularity, their connections with the rise of modern science and their reception in popular culture.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

CHC203Y1-Y-20259.courseTitle: Christianity and Society Through the Ages
CHC203Y1-Y-20259.courseDescription: This course explores the historical engagement of various Christian traditions with the prevailing political, social, and ethnic cultures in the western world and beyond. Students will also examine the development of Christianity as it confronts changes in the symbolic and intellectual universes from antiquity to post-modernity.
CHC203Y1-Y-20259.webTimetableInstructions: Timetable InstructionsThis course explores the historical engagement of various Christian traditions with the prevailing political, social, and ethnic cultures in the western world and beyond. Students will also examine the development of Christianity as it confronts changes in the symbolic and intellectual universes from antiquity to post-modernity.
CHC203Y1-Y-20259.breadthCategories: Society and its Institutions (3), Thought, Belief and Behaviour (2)

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

CHC215H1-F-20259.courseDescription: Christian history has been characterized by an enduring and fruitful search for forms of religious community. This course surveys some communal attempts to express Christianity, monasticism, forms of common life for clerics, the Mendicants, lay confraternities, religious orders, and contemporary lay movements.
CHC215H1-F-20259.webTimetableInstructions: Timetable InstructionsChristian history has been characterized by an enduring and fruitful search for forms of religious community. This course surveys some communal attempts to express Christianity, monasticism, forms of common life for clerics, the Mendicants, lay confraternities, religious orders, and contemporary lay movements.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

CHC232H1-S-20261.courseDescription: This course examines different models of relating Christianity and Science. Beginning with the biblical view on the natural world and moving to the present, the lectures develop a wide range of approaches.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

CHC308H1-S-20261.courseTitle: Marriage and the Family in the Catholic Tradition
CHC308H1-S-20261.courseDescription: A close reading of the Code of Canon Law touching on the themes of marriage and the family; relationship to other fundamental Church statements (e.g. Familiaris Consortio); examination of issues raised by opposition between church teaching and other views.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

CHC309H1-S-20261.courseDescription: This course explores developments in the relations between the Catholic Church and the states of Western Europe and America from the Enlightenment to the present. Of particular concern is Catholicism's response to the political theories of the Enlightenment, the secularization of the state and social justice issues.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

CHC312H1-F-20259.courseDescription: The Catholic Church has developed a distinctive approach to the pedagogical enterprise. This course explores aspects of this approach by an examination of canonical legislation and other texts published by ecclesiastical authorities and their application in Canada.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

CHC367H1-F-20259.courseDescription: This course introduces students to works of literary and dramatic arts from throughout the global Christian tradition. The course explores the complex relationships that exist between religious, narrative, and performative imperatives; between theological and cultural sources; between authority and experience; and between writers, playwrights, and their readerships and audiences.
CHC367H1-F-20259.webTimetableInstructions: Timetable InstructionsThis course introduces students to works of literary and dramatic arts from throughout the global Christian tradition. The course explores the complex relationships that exist between religious, narrative, and performative imperatives; between theological and cultural sources; between authority and experience; and between writers, playwrights, and their readerships and audiences.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

CHC390Y1-Y-20259.courseTitle: Independent Studies in Christianity and Culture
CHC390Y1-Y-20259.courseDescription: An independent research project to be proposed by the student and supervised by a Christianity and Culture faculty member. A full proposal including a course description, working bibliography, marking scheme, and approval from your academic supervisor must be submitted for approval by the Program Coordinator and Director. More information and application forms are available at https://stmikes.utoronto.ca/academic-forms or from the SMC Principal's Office, smc.programs@utoronto.ca. Completed forms must be submitted to the Principal's Office by the first day of classes in September/May for F courses, or January/July for S courses. Meeting times are determined in consultation with your supervisor, and may be in person or online as appropriate. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
CHC390Y1-Y-20259.prerequisite: Completion of 6.0 credits, at least 1.0 CHC credit.

CHC400H1-F-20259.courseTitle: Advanced Topics in Christianity and Culture I
CHC400H1-F-20259.courseDescription: An advanced seminar in Christianity and Culture as determined by the instructor.
CHC400H1-F-20259.webTimetableInstructions: Timetable InstructionsLEC0101 - Approaches to Ecological EthicsThe course will consider issues, documents, and ethical methods that will help the student to develop an understanding of the ecological crisis as well as ethical and theological responses to it. The limitations of a human-centered ethics, the need for an ecological justice that incorporates human justice, the implications of climate change, and the various Christian responses to the environmental issues are some of the topics that will be considered in the course.

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

CHC400H1-S-20261.courseTitle: Advanced Topics in Christianity and Culture I
CHC400H1-S-20261.courseDescription: An advanced seminar in Christianity and Culture as determined by the instructor.
CHC400H1-S-20261.webTimetableInstructions: Timetable InstructionsLEC0101 - Religious Experience in the World's ReligionsThis course explores the nature of religious experience (spirituality) in some of the major religions of the world, with special attention to Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Taoism, Native North American, Judaism, Islam and Christianity. It includes some comparative analysis between traditions, and creative reflection on the theological and pastoral significance of such comparative study.

LEC-0101.subtitle: Religious Experience in the World's Religions

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design

CHC471H1-Y-20259.courseDescription: Arranged by each student in consultation with faculty, the internship enables teacher candidates to integrate, extend and deepen their learning experiences in a way not otherwise available in the program. A description of the internship, working bibliography, marking scheme, and approval from your academic supervisor must be submitted for approval by the Program Coordinator and Director. More information is available from the SMC Principal's Office, smc.programs@utoronto.ca. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

CHC472H1-S-20261.courseTitle: Research Seminar in Christianity and Culture
CHC472H1-S-20261.courseDescription: The seminar provides majors in their final year of study with the opportunity to pursue advanced research projects in Christianity and Culture.
CHC472H1-S-20261.prerequisite: Completion of 10.0 credits; Students must be enrolled in the CHC Major program.
CHC472H1-S-20261.webTimetableInstructions: Delivery InstructionsLEC0101 - Liturgy and Music in the Roman Catholic Tradition The first part of the seminar will explore Trinitarian foundations of music and liturgy, in and since Vatican II, focusing on the imagery of Word and Breath, the priesthood of Christ, and the ecclesiology of communion. The second part will develop and apply this understanding to diverse musical experience and ministry (the singing assembly, cantors, choirs, the organ and other instruments, priest and deacon as music ministers, composers and hymn writers). This seminar is primarily theological and liturgical in focus: experience of music in church is more valuable than technical musical skills (musical skills are useful and welcome but not essential).

enrollmentControls.primaryOrgName: John H. Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, & Design
